VOL. XXXI. No. 2
BARNSTORMERS CLUB TO
HOLD FIRST MEETING
THURSDAY
TWO One-act Plays Are Planned for
Prospective Frosh
Candidates

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 5, 1926

THIRTY-FIVE ROOTERS
ACCOMPANY TEAM
TO PENN
About thirty-five rooters followed the football team to
Penn last Saturday. The majority journeyed to Philadelphia late Friday and stayed
at fraternity houses over
night. The team did not go
up until Saturday morning.
Unfortunately, however, the
local contingent was unorganized and spread over a
large section of the stands assigned to Hopkins, making efficient cheering almost impossible. A few scattered yells
issued forth sporadically, but
it is doubtful if any were loud
enough to be heard on the
field.

LUCK

Considerable comment has been occasioned by the early dates set
this year for class elections. No doubt some of this unfavorable criticism has been just. With little or no advance notice, members of the
Senior and Junior classes, in the midst of the turmoil brought about by
the selecting of courses, the extra effort required to once more set the
, wheels of activities in motion, and the absorbing spectacle of the first
freshman-sophomore run-ins, were called upon to make nominations
for class officers or student councilmen. On the next day they were
followed by the sophomores.

Evidently, Dartmouth, last year
considered by many leading authorities as the best team in the
country, will have another excellent
team this season despite the loss of
that great forward passing combination of Oberlander to Tully.
In the opening game Norwich
was smothered 59-0 and according
to reports another forward passing
team consisting of Dooley and Lane
was discovered.
Although Oberlander, last year's
All-American back is not at Dartmouth this year, the backfield is expected to be equally as strong as
last year's quartet.
Captain Horton, Lane and McPhail, who with Oberlander were
the regular ball carriers last season,
have returned to college and Dooley.
a star two years ago, but ineligible
last year because of studies, has
made up his deficient work, and is
now the fourth member of the backfield.

T

C. C. Pyle, the professional
football and tennis magnate, made
a great move towards strengthening professional tennis when he
signed Vincent Richards last week.
Richards during the past season
had a better record than Tilden and
has ranked either second or third
among the first ten for the last several years.
Harvey Snodgrass, who comes
from the Pacific Coast, also turned
professional last week and "Cold
Cash" Pyle, as he is sometimes
called, will probably arrange a tour
with Snodgrass and Richards playing in the larger cities of the country, along with Mlle. Lenglen and
Miss Browne.

Aside from the possible thwarting of any of the enterprising young
campus politicians, whose existence is as a matter of fact large by mythical, this decidedly precipitate gathering of the clans was unfortunate.
Class office and Student Council membership, although not matters of
life and death importance, nevertheless ought to be considered in a
fairly serious frame of mind, both for the honor involved and their
opportunity for service to class and university. Those that know anything whatever about class elections know that nominations are fully
DORM

V. B. Wight Addresses Meeting;
Rodgers and Magicians
Entertain Audience

About two hundred freshmen
and upper classmen attended the
annual reception given Friday night
by the Hopkins Y. M. C. A. in honor of the first year men. Lowell S.
Ensor, vice-president of the "Y"
was in charge of the entertainment.
Fraternity rushing parties were
much in evidence.

Scull, Rogers for Freeman, Westgate for Butler, Hayes for Thayer, Monte for Parke, McGinnis for

VOL. XXXI. No. 2
BARNSTORMERS CLUB TO
HOLD FIRST MEETING
THURSDAY
TWO One-act Plays Are Planned for
Prospective Frosh
Candidates

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 5, 1926

THIRTY-FIVE ROOTERS
ACCOMPANY TEAM
TO PENN
About thirty-five rooters followed the football team to
Penn last Saturday. The majority journeyed to Philadelphia late Friday and stayed
at fraternity houses over
night. The team did not go
up until Saturday morning.
Unfortunately, however, the
local contingent was unorganized and spread over a
large section of the stands assigned to Hopkins, making efficient cheering almost impossible. A few scattered yells
issued forth sporadically, but
it is doubtful if any were loud
enough to be heard on the
field.

LUCK

Considerable comment has been occasioned by the early dates set
this year for class elections. No doubt some of this unfavorable criticism has been just. With little or no advance notice, members of the
Senior and Junior classes, in the midst of the turmoil brought about by
the selecting of courses, the extra effort required to once more set the
, wheels of activities in motion, and the absorbing spectacle of the first
freshman-sophomore run-ins, were called upon to make nominations
for class officers or student councilmen. On the next day they were
followed by the sophomores.

Evidently, Dartmouth, last year
considered by many leading authorities as the best team in the
country, will have another excellent
team this season despite the loss of
that great forward passing combination of Oberlander to Tully.
In the opening game Norwich
was smothered 59-0 and according
to reports another forward passing
team consisting of Dooley and Lane
was discovered.
Although Oberlander, last year's
All-American back is not at Dartmouth this year, the backfield is expected to be equally as strong as
last year's quartet.
Captain Horton, Lane and McPhail, who with Oberlander were
the regular ball carriers last season,
have returned to college and Dooley.
a star two years ago, but ineligible
last year because of studies, has
made up his deficient work, and is
now the fourth member of the backfield.

HE Parker Duofold point

T

C. C. Pyle, the professional
football and tennis magnate, made
a great move towards strengthening professional tennis when he
signed Vincent Richards last week.
Richards during the past season
had a better record than Tilden and
has ranked either second or third
among the first ten for the last several years.
Harvey Snodgrass, who comes
from the Pacific Coast, also turned
professional last week and "Cold
Cash" Pyle, as he is sometimes
called, will probably arrange a tour
with Snodgrass and Richards playing in the larger cities of the country, along with Mlle. Lenglen and
Miss Browne.

Aside from the possible thwarting of any of the enterprising young
campus politicians, whose existence is as a matter of fact large by mythical, this decidedly precipitate gathering of the clans was unfortunate.
Class office and Student Council membership, although not matters of
life and death importance, nevertheless ought to be considered in a
fairly serious frame of mind, both for the honor involved and their
opportunity for service to class and university. Those that know anything whatever about class elections know that nominations are fully
DORM
as important as the election itself, and also that in making intelligent
DOINGS
nominations, a little time and thought are necessary, at least to the average run of mortals.

V. B. Wight Addresses Meeting;
Rodgers and Magicians
Entertain Audience

About two hundred freshmen
and upper classmen attended the
annual reception given Friday night
by the Hopkins Y. M. C. A. in honor of the first year men. Lowell S.
Ensor, vice-president of the "Y"
was in charge of the entertainment.
Fraternity rushing parties were
much in evidence.

Scull, Rogers for Freeman, Westgate for Butler, Hayes for Thayer, Monte for Parke, McGinnis for

for Miller, F. Scull for Schaff,

for McGinnis, Fields for Murphy, Douglas for Rogers, Odione for P. Scull, Mulligan for
Wascolonis, Sullivan for Thayer,
Lenzner for F. Scull, Kishner for
Butler, Walker for Hatre, Fonde
for Smith, Poole for Duncan, Sanford for Parke, Thompson for
Fields, Freeman for Douglas.

Rogers, Murphy, P. Scull. Try
for point—Lyons (place kick),
Wascolonis, 3 (place kicks), P.
Scull (dropkick).
